title: Peter Carey webchat â as it happened | Books | The Guardian
summary: on persevering in his career : 'if i 'd known how long it would take , i may well have given up '
'my next novel deals with matters i have wanted to write about all my life '
'i have spent a great deal of time dredging the silt unconscious , leaving a nasty mess on my desk '
'i still have plans for an alien abduction novel '

documents.title: no , wait
text: actually , just time for one more from peter !
answering goldie goldbloom who posted a question on facebook : in your work , landscape holds emotion for some of the characters that have a hard time verbalizing how they feel about things .
what helps you notice these sensory impressions , and do you have some favourite places to go to when you need to recapture the landscape ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:34pm goldie goldbloom , you are a wonderful writer .
on the evidence of the paperbark shoe there is not much i can teach you about landscape and emotion .
your process may be more conscious than mine which , as far as am aware , is intuitive .
( and nice to meet you like this )

documents.title: and that 's a wrap
text: that 's all that peter has time for huge thanks to him for his excellent answers .
his latest novel amnesia is out now , and can be bought from the guardian bookshop .

billythefish asks : having had numerous rejections from a multitude of agents , i have gone along with self publishing , for sales by amazon and kindle.should i have stuck it out and gone for even more rejections or do you think that i have taken the right route ?
also , is self publishing and internet sales the future ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:21pm i do n't know how long your road has been so far .
for most of us that road is very steep and very long .
for me it took ten years ( and 4 unsatisfactory novels ) before i was published ( the fat man in history ) .
i have never self published .
i do n't know of any literary writers who have .
amazon , it is true , can sell a chosen book like no-one else on earth but a publisher will also also help you edit it and , most important of all , market it .
this is the vital element , it seems to me .
you want the world to know your book actually exists .
you want it reviewed .
publishers are good at this .
of course rejection letters are total shit .
we never do forget them .

documents.title: on persevering in his career : 'if i 'd known how long it would take , i may well have given up '
text: from helen steadman on facebook : your persistence is really impressive - to keep on writing after your first books did n't make it into print - it gives me hope to keep on writing .
how did you keep the faith to keep going ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:15pm if i 'd known how long it would take , i may well have given up .
however i was always writing and by the time one work was being rejected i was onto something else which i knew was so much better .

and all along the way there were small encouragements , a piece in an anthology , a novel that was accepted before it was n't , and most of all my friend barry oakley , a published writer , ten years older .
ted solotaroff wrote a wonderful essay about all this , ten years in the cold .
highly recommended .
from ben figgis on facebook : were you influenced by john pilger 's account of the dismissal ?
if so , what were your impressions of that and how does yours differ ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:11pm pilger has been such a dedicated and consistent witness from the beginning .
i read secret country on its original publication and i have referred to it many times in the years since .
there is no better history available that i know of , and it is , as a history , complete in a way that my novel can not be .
from dave lawrence on facebook : having read and enjoyed all of your novels , i found my lack of knowledge of australian history made amnesia harder to totally understand .
as an international author , living in america , was this a conscious decision to get back to your roots ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:07pm i grew up reading novels from other cultures .
flaubert , for instance , garcia marquez , tolstoy , faulkner this has always been the great attraction of literature , to inhabit other places , histories , people unlike myself .
that being said , in amnesia i did my best to think about those readers who did not know australian history .
i would hope there are sufficient breadcrumbs to lead you through the forest and the strangeness of it might compensate for the lack of familiarity .
as for my roots , not really .
i just write about what interests me .
from kelly ana morey on facebook : speaking of australian histories ever been tempted to write about sid nolan and sunday reed ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:03pm what a fabulous story , but not one for me .
just the same i carry one detail : fred williams ' restoration of the kelly paintings sunday had left stacked around the walls .
fred 's one job : cleaning off the cat 's piss .
( highly reliable source )

documents.title: 'my next novel deals with matters i have wanted to write about all my life '
text: from dusan zabrdac on facebook : what 's your next novel going to be about ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 3:00pm a certain amount of secrecy is vital if one is going to keep up the head of steam that 's necessary .
enough to say it all takes place in australia and it deals with matters i have wanted to write about all my life .
i believe i have found a way .
from alix hawley on facebook : where do you begin - an image , a word ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:57pm oscar and lucinda makes the easiest illustration .
i was living in north new south wales when the bishop of grafton decided to take a pretty little church away from the banks of the never never .

i thought of how that church got to be there , how this box of christian stories entered a landscape filled with aboriginal stories and how the aboriginal stories were destroyed and how we no longer needed the church .
this lead to an image , the box of christian stories floating on a raft , entering the landscape filled with the stories it would destroy .
the characters of oscar and lucinda were born from this .
irishexile asks : do you agree that the arts are increasingly dominated by privately educated boarding school types such as yourself ?
how do we democratise the arts so that talented kids from all backgrounds get a fair crack of the whip ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:50pm you democratise the arts by acting as if you are living in a cruel and inequitable society .
when there is no-one living in poverty and when the prisons have been emptied of their state defined demographic , we might be almost on our way to the state you and i both desire .
no-one who knows me or my background would call me a boarding school type .
ps : should i be aware of the novels of d cameron ?

documents.title: 'i have spent a great deal of time dredging the silt unconscious , leaving a nasty mess on my desk '
text: from peter 's facebook page , jeannette brentnall asks : your books are treasures of literature , and while it may be too mundane to answer , i 'd be interested to learn how you go about writing .
william dalrymple uses a card system to keep track of the events in his historical works , and i wonder how you begin to construct a novel .
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:47pm i also have used cards .
i have constructed elaborate maps which have taught me nothing .
i have spent a great deal of time dredging the silt unconscious , leaving a nasty mess on my desk .
mostly i talk nonsense to my computer , circling , repeating , misspelling , mistyping .
i number things a great deal .
it is a fretful process making new order from chaos .
steveguy asks : g'day .
you clearly have maintained your rage but how do you feel about malcolm fraser 40 years after that terrible event ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:42pm i do n't spend a lot of time thinking about malcolm fraser .
i have a sense that he has rehabilitated himself .
i am sure he regrets his crime against democracy as much as i do .

peter olm asks : how much time do you spend visiting australia ( in particular melbourne ) and how do you go about maintaining an up-to-date , accurate feel for the places you 've written about in australia in recent novels ( amnesia , his illegal self ) , despite not living here ?
thanks for the great novels , peter !
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:40pm my family live near melbourne .
i try to get there once a year .
i lived in or near melbourne for about thirty years , so it does end up under one 's skin .
when writing amnesia i spoiled myself with a research trip which was a lot of fun .
i hope everyone all my friends who asked why in the fuck would you want to go to coburg ? '
find a good answer in the novel .
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:55pm in addition : i do n't have to carry all of melbourne inside my head .
who ever could ?
a novel will inevitably deal with certain streets , areas , rivers , trees of which i have vivid memories .
in the case of amnesia i i spent hours on the phone from new york .
friends sent me photographs and argued with me .
i read a lot .
i lived on google earth .
then i flew to melbourne with a yellow highlighter .
and lastly , of course , i have an excellent melbourne publisher who would never knowingly let me make a dick of myself .
marcusko15 asks : how do you renew your love for reading in an age where no one reads ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:37pm reading is like exercise , you have to do it long enough to feel the endorphins .
you need to do it regularly before you get the pay off .
lastly , understand that an ipad actually keeps you awake , so if you fall asleep while reading , this will keep you awake and add hours to your reading life .
also , probably best to stop drinking at the point the lines go blurry .
honey barbara asks : i 'm still trying to work out ' your short story report on the shadow industry ' - is there any definitive things you could say about it ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:33pm just let it percolate .
meliors asks : i 've just finished amnesia this morning , and have resolved to find a history of the gough whitlam era , which i really knew nothing about before reading your novel .
how much of that part of your story is based on fact ?
and what would you recommend for a novice to australian politics read to find out more ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:31pm you could do no better than to read john pilger 's a secret country .
this blogpost is also interesting .

electricnick asks : hi peter , are you the peter carey that stayed at the house we just moved out of in devils elbow , adelaide ( came into our restaurant ( annies kitchen ) with your sister in 1973 ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:27pm alas , i never travelled with my sister .
monsoonmaniac asks : started reading chemistry of tears with huge hope .
it has a gripping beginning , but then lost my way due to the complexities of the plot .
do you keep in mind an international audience while planning a plot ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:25pm i do n't really know how i could think of an international audience without going totally nuts .
i hope for patient , trusting literary readers .
i try to make it easy .
i would prefer them to enjoy themselves .
polstar2505 asks : true history of the kelly gang is remarkable because of the way you created ned kelly 's voice .
how did you decide what his voice would be like , and was it hard to sustain it over the course of the book ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:23pm the voice was where i started .
the voice was ned 's dna .
i found it in the jerilderie letter which he naively left to be printed and distributed .
i always loved the run on sentences , the desire to be understood , the sense of irish grievance and history .
the voice was familiar to me from life at bacchus marsh state school , the way people would say 'were ' instead of 'was ' and vice versa .

it was not at all hard to sustain but it was nice , from time to time , to give myself and the reader a tea break , and then i switched to rewritten newspaper reports which were a more effective way to present the narrative of the gang 's brilliant hold-ups .
yomyock asks : why do you write ?
what drives you ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:20pm the desire to make something beautiful that has never existed on the earth before .
naturally i have trouble sleeping .
andrewgilchrist asks : if you could ask ned kelly a question , what would it be ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:19pm did you never think about the legs ?
daffyddw asks : my favourites are the tax inspector and my life as a fake ( i seem to have a taste for grim ) - did a car dealer really piss you off that much ?
i would n't be surprised and what a come back !
and in mlaaf was that out of anxiety that peter carey has an independent life to peter carey ?
i only ask because a friend of mine ( a poet ) has invented an alter-ego so she can write about things from a different viewpoint and i 'm always holding up your book as a dire warning .
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:17pm my experience with car dealers is pretty much limited to my family who i have remained close to all my life .
that is , they were car dealers in a town called bacchus marsh and i chose that sort of business only because i imagined i knew all about it and that i would n't need to research .
of course by the time i wrote the tax inspector these sorts of dealerships had almost disappeared so i found myself researching , sitting in the spare parts departments of dinosaur enterprises .
the darkness of the tax inspector came from the world around me , not my loving normal family .

documents.title: 'i still have plans for an alien abduction novel '
text: digit asks : did you start out intending to only write science fiction ?
what propelled away from this ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:13pm i did not begin writing science fiction .
my early unpublished work shows a drunken embrace of beckett , robbe grillet , jorge luis borges , but also jp donleavy and roald dahl .
i have always believed that everything is made up , that there is no such thing as realism .
when sci-fi readers embraced me i hugged them right back .
i never had a prejudice against little green men .
i still have plans for an alien abduction novel .
malunkey asks : it seems unlikely to me that a real-life national legend should provide the material for outstanding works of high art .
yet for some reason ned kelly has ( i 'm thinking particularly of the sidney nolan paintings and the true history of the kelly gang ) .
often big characters and bold exploits can obstruct or crowd out the literary ( or painterly ) imagination , which tends to find purchase in odd angles and obscure corners .
why do you think ned kelly is such fertile ground for the creative imagination ?
is it something specific about the man or the legend ?
or has it something to do with the australian identity ?
or do you think i 'm wrong in my general analysis and that it is not unlikely or unusual at all ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:09pm one might look to shakespeare and the history plays for comfort .
anglida asks : reading your novels and short stories i am always impressed at your remarkable ability to inhabit the characters and the particular period or milieu you are writing about .
more so than many writers .
do you do absolutely tons of research ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:07pm i do a lot of research then throw most of it away .
one of the great values of research is to understand the physical and social restrictions that the characters have to act against .
the other is that it leads you to that moment when you are so deep into a world or era that you have the power to invent authentically .
that 's when my life starts .
1crossstreet asks : would you agree paul keating was the most intellectual of recent australian prime ministers ?
did australians duck his call for a mature sense of nationhood ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:04pm just remember what the present incumbent said : coal is vital for the future energy needs of the world .
he added that coal was good for humanity .
jeez louise .
this is not setting the intellectual bar very high .
but yes , of course , keating was very smart ( and exceptionally witty as well . )
but one great man is clearly not enough for us all to liberate ourselves .

documents.title: and we 're off
text: peter carey is up bright and early in new york , and giving his responses to your questions .
first up : jordan knowles asks : how is it possible to write something so meticulously detailed as oscar and lucinda and not want to renounce all writing duties forthwith and become a milkman ?
guardian contributor petercarey1 06 january 2015 2:01pm thinking of the details of a milkman 's life , it 's stressing me out .
my writing duties ' , on the other hand , are mostly fun .

documents.title: post your questions for peter carey
text: peter carey may now be a bestseller , and one of only three novelists to win the booker prize twice , but in our age of instant online fame his rise to prominence seems almost painfully protracted .
he began writing in the mid-60s during a career in advertising , where he could take on novels with the mental energy left over from copywriting , but his first five works never made it into print .
it was fifteen years after these first ventures into fiction that his debut novel bliss finally emerged .

since then he 's had big hits with counterfactuals like jack maggs , which was great expectations reimagined from the point of view of magwitch , and the true history of the kelly gang , which focused on the infamous hero of carey 's homeland , ned kelly .

in his latest novel amnesia , he tackles another period of australian history : the 1975 crisis in which the elected prime minister gough whitlam was controversially ousted , populating it with a vibrantly dickensian cast of characters .
he 's joining us to discuss it and anything else from across his career , in a live webchat from 2pm gmt onwards on tuesday 6 january .
post your questions in the comments below , and he 'll endeavour to answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The two-time Booker-winning author of Amnesia answered your questions, discussing his next novel, how he immerses himself in Melbourne and how he still wants to write an alien abduction novel.
